div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, April 19, 1901
div1.p:
Surgeon General Sternberg, U. S. A., is
perhaps the highest living authority on
yellow fever. For more than a quarter of
a century he has made it a study, and to
that task he has brought not only special
equipment as a microscopist and bacteri-
ologist, but the keen, original intelligence
so indispensable to any useful exploitation
of that equipment. Dr. Sternberg has not
investigated yellow fever as a mere ab-
straction. He has united theory with
practice, and has cemented the union
with long, careful, and enlightened inves-
tigation. What he says upon this most
important subject is therefore of the
profoundest interest. It represents both
authority and information, knowledge and
brains.

The Surgeon General's address to the
Social Science Association, Wednesday
evening, was devoted to yellow fever. It
was delivered without reference to notes
or memoranda-unnecessary aids in his
case--and was on that account all the
more attractive and impressive. His hear-
ers felt, of course, that he spoke of what
he surely knew and understood, and had
no missgivings as to his passing the bound-
ary of ascertained and demonstrated
fact. Thus, when he declared that the
source, the germ, of the malady is un-
known he disposed at once of the clamor
of a tiresome and noisy swarm of quacks
who have for years past laid claim to
this or that discovery and impudently be-
sieged the public mind with their ridicu-
lous and unwarranted pretensions. Dr.
Sternberg has examined almost every one
of these imagined scientific triumphs and
found them without merit. Long ago he
ranged himself with the leading yellow
fever experts of the South, who, after a
lifetime of patient and enlightened search,
had rejected not only the germ, but the
fifth theory and honestly confessed that,
so far, they had sought in vain. He took
no one's word, of course; he sought for
himself, but the result was a repudiation
of all the pretended discoveries. Again,
Dr. Sternberg spoke for the most experi-
enced yellow fever specialists in discard-
ing the contagion hypothesis. No really
intelligent observer--qualified by practice
and opportunity--believes that yellow
fever can be transmitted from one person
to another by mere contact. The statis-
tics of the great Gulf city institutions,
such as the Hotel Dieu and the Charity
Hospital of New Orleans, forbid the
thought. The records of the parish prison,
in the same city, show that no one ever
contracted the disease because of proxim-
ity, no matter how close, with a patient.
The history of the Howard Association--a
charitable society, founded fifty years ago,
and having ramifications in every Gulf
town formerly visited each year by yellow
fever--this history shows that non-im-
munes have nursed the fever's victims
year after year, occupying the same room,
often sleeping on their beds, without con-
tracting the disease in consequence. Dr.
Sternberg has compiled and analyzed these
statistics, subjected them to the inquisi-
tion of his perfected knowledge, and now
confers upon them the sanction of his
great authority.

Thus far The Post can fairly claim an
independent and original concurrence with
Surgeon General Sternberg. We have for
years insisted upon both these points, and
with no backing other than our own ex-
perience, observation, and study of scien-
tific declaration in the premises. To Dr.
Sternberg's further pronouncement touch-
ing the theory of transmission through
the agency of the mosquito we naturally
give our prompt adherence. We do not
understand Dr. Sternberg as saying that
the mosquito is the only medium of com-
munication. Our reading of his statement
is that he regards it as unquestionable,
and from such a source this opinion is en-
titled to acceptance on all hands. Touch-
ing the future exploitation of this hypoth-
esis, we claim no gift of prophecy. With-
out question it should be exploited to the
utmost. Meanwhile, Dr. Sternberg has
rendered inestimable service to the cause
of common sense and civilization. If we
can only destroy the stupid and cruel su-
perstitions upon which Southern quaran-
tines have been conducted so long and so
disastrously, we shall have taken a long
step in the direction of the light.
